review_title: Do your research about the program
pros: A nice little town with friendly people, smart and highly skilled professors, and plentiful resources for you to get support for your professional development, statistics-related questions, and things like literature search and so on. Also, Grad School Ombudsperson is an amazing person and will genuinely try to resolve your issues. My GA contract was 9 months, and my department paid me during the summers for some research and administrative work, which is something I appreciate.
cons: The entire school: Low pay, lack of housing support for graduate students, and on top of these, they cut $350 (monthly) from the stipend which is already low. My department: Toxic work environment, judgemental professors (even one or two can easily ruin the workplace climate), lack of emotional support, not enough grad courses for the subject matter they are expecting us to be experts on. Extreme publication pressure and no "actionable" support. In fact, they are currently forcing some tenured faculty to retire. These toxic professors are dropping an immense workload on Ph.D. students and still expecting them to publish in elite journals in the span of the Ph.D. (quick note: in my field, it takes 7 years on average to publish, and you get 4 or 5 years of funding for Ph.D. so you do the math).

review_title: Experience will depend on your PhD advisor - choose carefully
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Pros: - Rural, small-town feel - Relatively safe, low crime - Cost of living is relatively low (although housing costs are increasing) - Graduate school staff are nice and helpful Pros unique to my experience: - Fully funded throughout PhD - Was able to graduate in 5 years - Advisor, although often unavailable, was kind, considerate, and honest.
cons: Cons: - Excessive fees (>$2k per year) that cannot be covered by research stipends - Many professors are narcissists and not good mentors (Likely true at most research universities) - As a PhD student, you will be completely at the mercy of your PhD advisor and committee, so choose wisely (true as most research universities). - Minimal work options for spouses/partners in Blacksburg. - Funding can be stressful depending on your sources of funding - Difficult to leave Blacksburg since there is not a major airport nearby - Blacksburg will feel very small by the end of your PhD. There are limited things to do or places to explore. You may end up feeling very stuck. Cons unique to my experience: - PhD advisor largely uninvested in my research and did not provide much mentorship or guidance with research. - Collaborations with additional groups caused tension around authorship and manuscript readiness for submission. Collaborating professors dragged their feet on manuscript submission and caused some manuscripts to take years to complete (delaying my timeline for graduating). - PhD qualifying exam (Mechanical Engineering) was extremely stressful.

Having a similar job in the private industry would yield at least a 30% increase. It is very hard to get a pay raise outside of the "yearly" raises that all state employees receive in accordance to the state's approved budget. If you get stuck in a department with a senior leader that doesn't recognize your or your group importance, it makes for a miserable work environment because there is little avenue to remedy this. Leaders can make your working life very hard, on purpose, and label their actions as innovation making it hard to prove malice intent.

review_title: the student admin/education side is horrible/toxic to work at
pros: The organization is prestigious and large, if you truly want to learn to explore and learn how other functions work, you can. (it's limited as a part-time though)
cons:
This comment is made for my experience working on the admin/education side only. I have great experiences working in different departments as a hokie alum. It is just to my surprise, that this particular experience in admin/education is horrible and toxic.

The admin/education side is really meant to work closely with students, which is the most vibrant element of the community. However, the majority of the people I worked with all seem to be ready for retirement without too much energy. They can be energetic when bragging about the "big things" but the purpose is to really impress and inflate performance reviews for pay raises or promotions, in reality, they aren't doing anything that contributes to any factual development. 

They asked me at least 3 questions about diversity (I'm not white) during interviews, but it does not change the fact that is a predominately white institute governed by old white leadership and they do so little to engage the younger and diverse employees. I did not feel belonged at all! I've raised concerns about DEI but got no hear back from the leadership team, not even a reply in email. 

People do not take responsibility for what they say or do because no one seems to care enough. Seniority exists in a way that hurts morale and engagement, I worked with an employee who is in a position long enough but for some reason, they just keep making simple mistakes, instead of being transparent about it, they would choose to cover it up until is discovered. I'm not sure if the leadership does anything to help these employees grow despite a simple mistake that ended up costing $2000. I was told, instead, to respect people and be polite because I'm not accepting enough.

It is more ridiculous that at the end of the year during a performance review, the direct reports made comments about my personal values and ethics not being flexible, saying that I'm not cut out for this job because of this. The student admin/education side of the university just doesn't deserve to be served.

job_title: PhD Graduate Researcher in New York, NY
pros: With my graduate research position. I had a decent amount of flexibility in research topic. I was able to overlap my paid research with my PhD progress. I had health insurance that sort of covered what I needed (therapy). And my boss (PhD advisor) was pretty reasonable. But I was one of the lucky ones.
cons: My friends who weren't white, able bodied, or men had many many stories to tell me of their discrimination. Being asked to leave the country, holding student-visa's over GRA's heads to overwork them, discriminatory wages, having their research findings shot down off-handedly after years of rigorous and fruitful effort. Graduate students have less rights for solving disputes at VT, compared to graduate students elsewhere. Luckily a battle was recently won to improve grad student pay, but that doesn't fix all the problems, and I saw many at VT.

review_title: Hostile Work Environment, Education Discrimination, Disability Discrimination, and Sexual Harassment
job_title: IT Applications Developer in Blacksburg, VA
pros: - It gave me something to laugh and shake my head at for 2 years and 4 months. (Trying to be positive here)
cons:
- Leadership oppresses and abuses employees as if they're not equal humans.
- VT does not respect or value experience.
- VT promotes toxic individuals in to leadership.
- VT enables bullying.
- VT could not provide someone with my experience with enough work to keep me busy.
- VT Leadership is not trustworthy and does not stand by their words. I was told I would receive a salary increase after my 1 year probation, only took the job because of this promise, and the salary increase never happened. Instead, the individual I submitted complaints to the director about for that entire year received a promotion to assistant director.
- During my first week of employment my immediate supervisor told me that he, "regretted hiring me." He refused to collaborate with me for the rest of my employment.
- This same immediate supervisor made inappropriate comments about my body.
- This same immediate supervisor would not collaborate with the team and would demand things go their way if someone offered a different approach.
- This same immediate supervisor was promoted to assistant director after all of the above issues had already been brought to the attention of the director.
- Software development team with no documented standards operating on a out-dated codebase built without reading the framework's documentation. I rebuilt this codebase in two weeks, the director instructed the team to use it, and the team refused.
- It was not uncommon to hear, “this is how it’s done at Virginia Tech,” when offering new solutions and alternative approaches.
- Leadership can't be trusted - on any level.

review_title: Pretty good place to work overall
pros:
Experiences in a large university are largely influenced by the department and college and can vary widely depending on the particulars of your group.  So my comments may be quite different than those in other fields.
* flexiblity with how you spend your research time
* minimal committee work for Assistant professors; efforts on reducing their teaching loads
cons:
* Compared to our peer schools, our teaching loads are too high (4 courses per academic year vs. 3 at peers).  At the same time we offer much lower summer support (1/9 vs 2/9 at peers) and somewhat lower base salaries.  
* At the department level, our key decisionmakers' seem to have an over-inflated view of the deparment's status in the profession.  This can lead to counterproductive decisions.  We recently decided not to hire a senior person from another school because of concerns about his research; based on his record, this guy would have had the best research record in the department!
* Colleagues are "friendly" but not "collegial".  Many people rarely/ever come in to their office, there is very little/no mentoring

This is a big organization and like all big orgs you'll have good and bad. Generally speaking, however, I've been in this environment for 20+ years and I can say I've rarely heard a bad review. Virginia Tech is a good place to work, to grow, to stay or to be from. If you're looking, and something is available, I'd recommend you apply. Try it out.

review_title: It's a job in a small town with no jobs
pros: Cost of living in Blacksburg, VA is so low, that I have no problem living with a low income.  If I ever have a problem HR is always there to help. Benefits are great! If you are in need of experience, great place to get it. They offer free classes and training courses. I have never had a problem taking time off and we receive plenty of holiday hours. Our college loves to have potlucks, work environment is always fun/energetic and everyone at the school is very kind.
cons: Located in a very small town, without the school there would be nothing here. Don't expect to get away from students. Just to give you an idea, the next town over is properly named "Christiansburg" (so you may love it or hate it, sadly there is absolutely no in between), this town is what you make of it, not much here. No room for growth, getting a job in the school is tough, trying to move anywhere in the college is almost impossible. Do not get involve with school politics. You will have to pay over $120 for parking a year and will never find a parking spot (they are even building on existing parking areas so parking will be reduced in the coming years). So far my college has pushed two people into retirement, would not recommend this job for your career.

pros: Many different peoples from many different walks of life. This makes for an enriching atmosphere working alongside those from southwest Virginia and also the students from the more urban centers of Virginia. Working for an organization that caters to 20-somethings can bring about a pretty enjoyable day. I personally worked in Dining Services for the university which meant interacting with the students day in and day out. VTs has some of the best food in the country which brings great customer satisfaction which makes life as a server quite the breeze.
cons: The employee turnover rate that comes with working at a university makes for very difficult scheduling on both managements part and on those salary workers who have a bit more vested in the university as an employee. This makes for a bit of tension between the employed students and full-time workers. This tension can at times layout the atmosphere of the day. (As full time workers still have to drive in hellacious snowstorms while students who live a quarter of a mile away don't want to make the 5 minute trek to work that day.)

pros: Beautiful campus in a nice college town.
cons: It's all about "advancement" now -- bringing in money -- rather than education. Employee wages, treatment, and benefits vary widely depending on the college or center.  Low wages for staff employees; "faculty" positions -- whether teaching, research, or administrative -- have MUCH better pay and benefits (twice the annual leave and 26 weeks of full pay for sick leave/year versus eight days for staff!), and administrative faculty often have less education and experience than staff employees. Benefits such as teleworking and flexible hours are available to employees in some colleges but not others. No opportunity for professional development (no money to join professional associations or attend conferences). VT doesn't follow written policies regarding use of performance reviews or warnings to terminate employees but simply eliminates and renames positions.

review_title: Low salary compared to living cost
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: The location is really nice, and the weather is one of the best in the country.
cons: They pay less than any other university compared to living costs.

review_title: Great learning environment, good benefits, meh pay
job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Blacksburg, VA
pros: As you are working in a field that is constantly changing, requiring you to frequently re-up your skills and learn new things, a technical oriented school like Virginia Tech is a great place to work. Education benefits and access to great learning resources go a long way to improving your skill set, and are encouraged.
cons: While the benefits are good, the pay can be a good bit under the industry average. Couple this with the location - mostly rural southwest Virginia - and you are up against some tough odds to find meaningful competition to force salaries upward.

review_title: West End was a fun place to work, good balance of work/social life.
pros:
Management was very friendly, welcoming. 
The work was fast paced, so time goes by quickly. I worked in the Pizza shop, and had the opportunity to do something different each time I came to work. I could arrange my schedule around my availability, as a student, and only had to work 10 hours a week. It was easy to get time off for exams, sickness, etc. if necessary, as long as you tell your manager in advance. You get a free meal with every shift you work. I have never had any problems with the customers or employees- most are very nice and respectful. Every now and then, there will be an event hosted by management for the employees, e.g. movie night
cons: Some employees didn't really like their job, and it showed. Sometimes, communication is poor between chefs and store workers about inventory, and it is not uncommon to run out of one or more products.

review_title: Reasonable pay, if not for student fee deductions.
pros: Virginia Tech is a great place to work as a graduate student, the campus is beautiful and Blacksburg is relatively affordable; my rent comes to about 30% of my net income, and food, groceries, etc. to about another 40%. Of course the quality of the job when working as a GRA/GTA is highly dependent on who you are working with.
cons: The main issue I have is the student fees that are not covered by the assistantship. While on paper I make a pretty comfortable amount for a graduate student, in the neighborhood of $18,000 - $20,000 a year, student fees take about a $3,000 chunk out of that amount each year. There worryingly little transparency about these fees, especially considering that they continue to steadily increase.

review_title: Good Professional experience, lots of politics to advance.
pros: VT is a large school with plenty of things going on.  If you plan to work on Higher Education, the is a great place to gain experience and build your resume. Great opportunity to see "how the sausage gets made."
cons: As an Assistant Director, be prepared to work over 40hrs/week without overtime on a regular basis. In my experience innovation was not rewarded, more so who is willing to "play ball" even if the work is ineffective. High turnover for faculty and staff of color. The town of Blacksburg is nice if you have your own support network, otherwise it can be hard to find community, especially if you value diversity. Make sure to get everything in writing when discussing your benefits and professional development with with your boss, or bosses boss.

review_title: Great if you have a faculty position; not so great for staff
pros: Beautiful campus, high energy, great town.
cons: Depends on what college/office you work in. Some areas are much more flexible and allow employees to take advantage of benefits like flexible work hours, telework, etc. Other colleges/offices refuse to allow their employees to take advantage of university policies. No opportunities for travel to conferences, membership in professional organizations, etc., for staff in my office. Salary increases don't keep up with increases in health insurance, so it's impossible to get ahead.

review_title: Great environment to help better skills
pros:
- Great benefits.  
- Great people to work with.  
- Small development teams/shops allowed me to focus on all areas of the development stack without requiring me to specialize in one thing and stick to that one thing.  
- Management does a great job focusing on me as a person and helping me better myself professionally and as a person.
- Definitely an 8-5 job.  When I get off of work at 5, I don't have to worry about working at home to make a deadline, etc.  Had very, very few emergency calls to step in and fix issues.
cons:
- Being a state-funded university, there aren't the "normal perks" of being a software development shop, such as the Xboxes, ping pong tables, etc.  But, they try to make it comfortable with nice equipment and work areas
- Without being a large development company, sometimes, the development pipeline isn't very full or flushed out, which causes downtimes.  Not a huge issue, but does cause some thumb twiddling

review_title: A good choice for grad school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: The atmosphere is professional but not uptight. The school is competitive in a wide range of fields. Cost of living in Blacksburg is very low, to the point where most grad students can go out at least once a week. The town is glorious when the undergrads have left for summer vacation, as there's no lines, no waits at restaurants, and life is just easy. If you're interested in (or interested in trying) hiking, biking, kayaking, or running, you're going to love it here!
cons: The interdisciplinary programs can have a tough time keeping the curriculum up to date, simply due to the politics of trying to get professors to teach courses that won't help them with regards to their own departments. Blacksburg is far away from a "real" city; if you live off shopping trips and great Thai food, this is not the right town for you. You'll still find a ton of culture for such a tiny town, but probably not enough to satisfy you.

review_title: Responsibility level more than title & pay
job_title: Program Support Tech Senior in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Excellent Benefits, OT has to be approved; not SOP, excellent training opportunities, and one class free per semester if accepted into the University.  Excellent vacation and PTO program.
cons: University will shut down classes due to foul weather; let the faulty and executive management stay home.  But force administrative (secretaries, etc) drive in inclement weather even if you are non-essential.  I worked a position that had the level of responsibility of an executive assistant but the title and pay did not match.   They also have the habit of hiring student wives vs. promoting locals all ready experience and wanting to move up.  New employees get paid the same or more than veterans.

review_title: Good place to learn and work
job_title: Research Assistant, Student in Blacksburg, VA
pros: On the learning end, the school has a wide array of technical areas for study, LOTS of research opportunities, and an experienced and knowledgeable faculty.  On the working end, the university does what it can to accommodate your work schedule and school schedule.
cons: For a technical school, Virginia Tech really falls short in some areas.  There are very few online classes, the on-campus wireless service can be spotty, and a lot of the automatic grading programs for the computer classes have major bugs.  On top of it all, the school requires that you own a laptop for use in class but then doesn't have enough electrical sockets to plug in if you need to; it's getting better, but it's still a problem.

review_title: Amazing work atmosphere, challenging but reasonable work...
pros: Virginia Tech has research-oriented labs, that introduce the student employees to a variety of disciplines of research. Especially, the students get hands-on experience in the field, and can develop their professional side admirably in preparation for finding a job in the industry. I work in the microelectronics laboratory, and I am thoroughly indebted to the University to improve my technical expertise in the field of microelectronics.
cons: Ultimately, working at a University will only give you a perfunctory experience of what actually happens in the industry, and does not completely prepare you for the real world, since the job here is more or less fixed, unless you really screw it up with your advisor.

review_title: As a graduate student I had access to an excellent insurance plan and flexible hours.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: The student (and I presume full time employee) health and dental insurance are really good here, and the Blacksburg area is very safe. Insurance is 90% covered if you are on a GRA or GTA. Depending on your advisor, you may have a very flexible work schedule so you only have to come in for occasional meetings and are free to work when you want. This is especially nice if you are a night owl, like some of the students I know.
cons: If you are a grad student, your experience will vary greatly depending on your graduate advisor. The professor I worked for was more concerned with output than with your presence in the lab, so it was a nice environment since my schedule is usually a bit unpredictable.

review_title: Top notch engineering school for the money, industry respects the students and seeks employees from tech.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: This school has great sense of community, classes are challenging, professors are very well educated and up to date with emerging technologies (for the majority). Engineering here is wonderful, companies come to Virginia Tech seeking to hire both interns and full time positions. Keep a 3.0 gpa and you will not have a hard time finding professional opportunities as an engineer.
cons: Within the ECE department there should have been more emphasis on PCB design, and soldering. This was not covered in any required curriculum. There are senior level classes where this experience can be obtained. Electronic Circuit Design 2 and power electronics lab.

job_title: Web Applications Programmer in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Great benefits, pleasant environment (mostly), continuing education. If you are interested in continuing your education then VT is a great place to work as they will waive your tuition as long as the coursework benefits the current role you are working in.
cons: For IT folks it can be difficult to get raises. VT has lost a lot of talent simply because they pay their engineering personnel much less than what they can typically get in the private sector. Of course, health benefits and pleasant work environment often help compensate for this. You have to know what you're getting. If environment, stability, health insurance, etc. are important then VT is probably good for you. If you are looking to maximize your salary then I'd go elsewhere.

review_title: A great opportunity if you're in the area.
job_title: Educational Support Specialist in Blacksburg, VA
pros: This opportunity provides for a lot of time off, flexible work environment, and not too stressful. The Blacksburg community, including the Virginia Tech community, are also some of the most pleasant people I have had the opportunity to work with.
cons: It did not provide me with skills out of college to prepare me for work outside of a state funded organization. The pace is considerably slower than what is experienced in for-profit organizations. Furthermore, opportunities for advancement and salary increases are severely limited. Unless academia is your direction, then this type of position may not be for you due to it's lack of upward mobility.

review_title: Deet's Place was a fantastic place to work on campus
job_title: Student Assistant Manager in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
Flexible schedules. Great people(made some of my best college friends here). Free on campus meals when working.

Deet's Place was (IMO) by far the best place to work in the Dining Services Department at Virginia Tech as a student. The customers are generally friendly, the employees are awesome, and you get some free meals and coffee out of the deal as well.
cons:
Good not great salary, management getting stricter when I graduated. 

Some management turnover was when I graduated which made the work life a little stricter than in previous years. Though this was probably necessary for business purposes, the day to day work life was not as loose as in the past.

review_title: Fantastic employer in a small college town
pros:
World class university

Beautiful college town in the mountains of southwest VA

Competitive benefit package 

Numerous opportunities for professional development via skills workshops and campus courses 

Close-knit community and friendly work environment (everyone loves the Hokies!)

Great college sports scene

Low cost of living in the region

Overall an incredible place to work!
cons:
Blacksburg is not a large town and consequently lacks many big city amenities. The nearby town of Christiansburg (15 min drive) and city of Roanoke (40 min drive) however can usually provide whatever service/attraction that Blacksburg lacks.

Staff salaries are underwhelming but this is slightly offset by the generous benefit package and the region's low cost of living. 

Educational qualifications are important. If you do not have a masters you will eventually hit a ceiling regardless of how deserving you may be for a promotion and/or additional responsibilities.

pros: Excellent work life balance. My particular boss never enforced a strict schedule and he encouraged me to not work more than I had to. The university also has a very tight-knit atmosphere that bleeds into the work environment and makes working more enjoyable. Since I worked for a small research group I feel like I had a lot of chances to take on more responsibility and grow professionally.
cons: Lower than average compensation, but that is to be expected in a low cost of living area like Blacksburg. As an employee at VT I worked as a kind of contractor for state agencies. I think there is not as much recognition for that extension side of the university as there is for the research/academia side of the university.

job_title: Director of Development in Blacksburg, VA
pros: This can be a good place to make a name for yourself and the school has a great reputation in the US.  Internationally, it may not be as well known but that is not really a big deal.  Besides a great location in Blacksburg, Virginia it also has a great presence in Northern Virginia and this is very helpful with regard to targeting all the different government agencies.
cons: Unless you are on the tenure track it is harder to advance your career and in Blacksburg there still are not many other opportunities outside of the University.  Travel in and out of Roanoke airport (closest airport) is not very convenient and there are not many flights to choose from.

review_title: An excellent place to work for people with families and those who desire stress free life
pros: excellent benefits, good work-life balance, proximity to new blue ridge mountains and plenty of opportunities to do outdoor sports, excellent place to do continuing education and take courses. Enough leeway is  given in trying out new technologies. Since the employer is state of Virginia there is a great job stability and excellent retirement benefits as well.  The fear of layoffs is never there on the minds of people.
cons: Due to the lack of industries in the area there are less opportunities of growth. The only salary raises people usually get are not more than the standard inflationary raise allowed by the state of Virginia.

review_title: Great place to work. Its good to be a professor at virginia tech. The pay is pretty low and the bureaucracy is high.
job_title: Professor, College Or University in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
location is good
low stress

Blacksburg is a special place to live. Nice mountains and streams. Nice people. Good schools. Etc.
cons:
bureaucracy is not so good
low pay

There is a lot of crap work to be done from forms to certifications and the like. This gives you less time for teaching and research. The pay is lower than comparable schools and industry. Working here as a professor is a choice of lifestyle over pay. Staff are under valued and appreciated and there are a lot of under performs with  state mentality. The very good ones are over worked. So, tough on staff.

job_title: Food Production Supervisor in Richmond, VA
pros:
Good benefits, sick days, vacation, overtime opportunities which are not typical in a food service environment.

Opportunities for advancement are available if working at the right dining hall, and if performance is exemplary.

University offers tuition compensation programs for all salaried employees (with approval from management)

Summers are very relaxed since students are gone, and winter break is essentially optional if you have enough vacation. Imitate a student's schedule.
cons:
Salaries are much lower than in private sector, somewhat acceptable due to the low cost of living in Blacksburg but one would think that the best university dining program in the country would pay a little better.

Getting beyond a Food Production Supervisor and into management is fairly difficult, requiring years of commitment or previous experience.

review_title: Effective and I learned a lot.  It is just like an other graduate research position at a major university.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: You earn money to go to school.  Experience varies by professor and department, but it was an overall exciting experience.  My department and professor are very organized and professional and push you to succeed.  I am very satisfied with the work that I am doing and people are friendly for the most part.
cons: Buildings can be old and I have seen more than my share of cockroaches.  Also,  changing a position from research assistant to teaching assistant is difficult.  Also, if you are a teaching assistant then you can sometimes have more teaching assignments than you  can manage.

review_title: This higher education environment and VT in particular is a very exciting and dynamic place to work.
pros: The people are caring and engaged.  Great to work with.  The work is interesting and the environment is exciting to be a part of.  Management is very caring about their employees and supportive of a work/life balance. There are many educational classes and opportunities to improve your knowledge.
cons: Somewhat of a bureaucracy. However, I've seen a fast paced environment with very well educated employees at the helm.  Located in a small town.  Could be viewed as a con, but also a good thing.  Quality of life is above average.

pros: Virginia Tech is one of the best schools in the country for STEM fields, so you will be getting a very good education. It's in a quite place, which can be a good thing because there is more time to focus and there is a lot of activities occurring around the school.
cons: It is basically in the middle of nowhere, which can be a headache sometimes. Eventually the town feels small, and the nearest city is about three hours away. Also, the closest airport (Roanoke) is very small and doesn't provide many traveling alternatives.

review_title: I'm very happy with my experience as an MS student in FREC.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Graduate student salaries are competitive and in line with the cost of living in the area.  Leadership in my department is extremely supportive of graduate students.  The university overall is supportive of graduate education as well.
cons: Funding for research and travel can be a challenge, although this is likely the result of the national attitude toward research funding, not a product of the university itself.

pros: Scheduling is very easy and the job works around my school schedule. The job is not labor intensive (unless there is an installation). It is low maintenance and there is an opportunity to meet artists and be around pieces of artworks all day.
cons: I don't really have anything terribly bad to say about the position. The hours are short and there isn't really the opportunity for a lot of hours due to the number of employees.

review_title: Good place to work. Beautiful Campus. Middle of nowhere.
pros: Beautiful campus. Hokie stones are gorgeous. Relaxed atmosphere. Although I fell out with my manager, it took me a while to realize that I didn't have to worry about losing my job. Upper management were just as ineffective in dealing with my manager's unjustified complaints about me, as they were with my complaints about him. Once I realized this, I calmed down and focused on enjoying my time in VT and looking for new positions.
cons: Problematic manager showed the downside of VT. Management likes the status quo and do not like to take action to resolve issues. Too much favoritism.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Some great research being done at the institution with lots of opportunities to get involved. Very supportive atmosphere. The higher ups in the Mechanical Engineering department are focusing on larger and larger grants, so there are partnership opportunities with industry available.
cons: The GRA contract process can be a bit stressful as you have to renew your contract every semester. If you have an advisor who isn't on top of his/her paperwork, then you can find yourself in a last minute scramble to get funding. Constant writing of proposals and publications is a must in order to assure that your lab gets sufficient funding.

pros: Friendly environment, good  interaction for multidisciplinary research, knowledgeable staff, the ECE department, Luke Lester,  is outstanding.
cons: The yearly salary of the senior professors is too low.  It is currently around $105 K, which is way too low.

review_title: Virginia Tech - a good place to work
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia Tech is located in a wonderful area.  Co-workers are great to work with and management is fine. I enjoy the laid back, non-stress atmosphere.  It is much different than a corporate position where a bottom line is being chased each month.  There is more time to experiment and try new things.
cons: There is not a lot of growth potential.  Raises and bonuses are not part of the job.  It is a secure job but not one that will provide career growth.

review_title: My experience as a tutor at Virginia Tech has been fulfilling.
job_title: Tutor of Student Athletes in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia Tech allows you to choose your own hours, which makes it easy to work around my busy schedule. Having the ability to choose my own hours allows me to dictate when I work, how often I work, and therefore how much money I make per week.
cons: Some of the students that I tutor do not share the same work ethic that I do, which makes tutoring difficult. Due to some of my students' scant work ethic, It often seems like I am helping them pass their classes rather than helping them get A's.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Falls Church, VA
pros: It is a good place to learn new things. Lot's of new graduate students, and smart ones too. As a graduate student i got a lot of help from my professors, and they are all very intelligent and smart. It is a good place to go to school especially if you are in engineering. Would definetly recommend anyone to go there. Also you get funded atleast for one of the semesters if you are a graduate student.
cons: It's a university environment, so not a lot a scope to grow, but you get to learn a lot.

job_title: Power Plant Operator Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
The school has a gym that is free to employees.
Human Resources has a great open door policy
The school has a Weight Watchers group for employees as well as discounts on membership
cons:
You have to pay for parking
The employees don't receive email notifications when to sign for payroll deductions for parking passes, you have to check their e-newsletter.  If you miss the deadline you have to pay full price, which for one semester is about $180 and for the whole year $240-ish

review_title: I worked in the different shops throughout Owen's.
job_title: Dining Services- Owens in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Easy money, on campus, free meals, when working with people it's fun, work study option
cons: Some people take their job way too seriously, when it's time to clean up for the night, it's a mad house because so many people are trying to leave at once. Some employees are super fun, and some are the nastiest, and you just have to hope that you get put with the fun ones. the "free meal" is pretty much like half a meal, unless you eat like a child.

review_title: solid job till funding ran out
pros: The benefits were good especially insurance and retirement.  The work environment was good.  The dining halls on campus have good food and are convenient to walk to for lunch.  Busses available to those that live close, I was not able to utilize this though.
cons: The parking pass needed to park on campus is expensive.  The pay was not great for the level of education required for the job, relative to a job in industry.  Being under a grant funded technician position the grants ended and my job dissapeared before I was vested (5 years) for retirement.

review_title: try to start with a salary you will be satisfied with for a while...
pros: Lovely people to work with, high energy campus, interesting work.
cons: They will not back up and pay you more when your value goes up. You would most likely have to leave the department. In other words, if you were not a supervisor when you get hired, and then you become a supervisor, you will not get paid what they would pay a supervisor getting hired from the outside - at east that has been my experience.

review_title: Good University, flexibility in job, low-cost of living, good vacation.
pros: Flexibility, Can have good work-life balance with this job. Good benefits with 5 weeks of paid-vacation time. Blacksburg has a low cost of living. Also, the campus is beautiful. People are good since it is a small town. Schools in Blacksburg are good too.
cons: Growth may be restricted depending on position. Can get bureaucratic, In some departments there are restrictions on how much your pay can be raised. Since it is a small university town people feel the need to visit some big surrounding city like Washington, DC from time to time.

pros: Lots of opportunities for advancement. Generous vacation. Very stable workplace. Receive university benefits such as library card, access to fitness areas, and transportation.
cons: Fairly low pay. Very few opportunities for creative expression. If you don't take vacation in the summer you will be absolutely bored out of your mind.

review_title: Great Place to Live and Study
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: This is a quite small town (officially it is the largest town in Virginia) for living and studying. It is in the Appalachian mountains and good for outdoor exercise.
cons: A little far away from big cities. The nearest big city is Washington, D.C., which is 5 hours away. The nearest airport is Roanoke–Blacksburg Regional Airport, which is 40 minutes away.

review_title: Too much work for little pay!
pros: The best thing about VT is the people, friendly work environment.
cons:
Very little admin support in departments so expect a lot of work from everyone around you. VT saves budget funds by using the money to pay for more support and gives more to management and faculty to entice higher salary to work in Blacksburg.  Can be a top performer and little pay incentive offered. Do not work here in an admin role.  So overworked and little work life balance.
Also have to use own vac time for winter closing, 4 days.

review_title: I worked in a lab for the Biomedical Engineering and Mechanics (BEAM) dept. designing, building and testing experiments.
pros: I really enjoyed the bright and driven people I worked with. Being in a lab you are surrounded by PhD students and you get to learn about all the other projects going on in the lab.
cons: Sometimes the lab can have too much going on and everyone's stuff is packed into every corner. On occasion people have trouble finding things or having to share equipment and space but we were always able to figure it out and get things done.

review_title: Great people, good opportunities for student work
pros: The administration in general is very welcoming and nice. Student workers are given a good amount of responsibility and are treated with respect. Supervisors understand that this is temporary work and are not too hard on you. Depending on your position, schedules can be flexible and accommodate your class schedule.
cons: Lots of overlap of responsibilities among offices, resulting sometimes in miscommunication. Inter-dependencies of several departments compete with staff incentives to solve problems internally. Some staff have been there a long time and are generally pretty complacent.

review_title: Beautiful and actually peaceful place for study
pros: Beautiful town for study and living, good place to study. The living cost is relatively low. Bus brings you over the whole town conveniently. Nice and active people you will meet here. Compensation is normal, not better not worse though. Football events makes the town crowed but it is good experience.
cons: It is very cold at winter time. A little bit not that convenient for shopping. The research press is a little bit high. The entertainment activity is relatively not that convenient, for example, you need to drive to another close city for shopping or watching movie.

review_title: Biocomplexity Institute of Virginia Tech - IT (Blacksburg is for Wackos just read the news)
pros: Option of returning to school paid by Virginia Tech.  Willing to pay for certifications. ALOT of down time for studies!
cons: Manager was horrible at communication.  Had to open a trouble ticket to receive training. Manager never gauged technical ability and was afraid to share input and access to systems that were essential to performing role.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Good research and nice people.There are many programs and activities to give a complete student experience. Affordable place with multiple dining options.
cons: Small town with not many activities except hiking or what is organized by Tech (which is still a nice variety). Graduate student end up left alone from the multitude of events organized by (for?) undergrads. As in every institution the experience can vary based on your boss.

review_title: Personal Touch Catering is a great fit for college students.
pros: Personal Touch is an on-campus catering service that takes into consideration the fact that I'm a student and works to prevent conflicts between my work and class schedules. In addition to flexible hours, my coworkers are easy to get along with, and I get paid a reasonable amount of money.
cons: Really the only downside I can think of is that some events run longer or shorter than anticipated. In other words, though you might be scheduled to work "x" number of hours, you might end up working more or less, depending on the circumstances.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Great work environment. Great to get funded for your Masters. Stipends are reasonable considering low cost of living. Virginia Tech in general is filled with awesome people and great outdoor opportunities for the necessary stress relievers for your masters program
cons: Like any funded student, you will work hard. Balancing classes and research can become cumbersome. Sometimes, your left feeling burnt out and struggle to close out semester.

job_title: Public Speaking GTA in Blacksburg, VA
pros: I've been a graduate teaching assistant for the Communication department for a year and a half. The support the department offers is outstanding and you never feel like you can't talk to at least one person. The training they provide you to teach public speaking is conducted the week prior to school starting and it is very thorough. I felt well prepared to teach come the first day of classes.
cons: I would imagine being a public speaking GTA for the department would be difficult if you were terrified of public speaking, had poor time management, and were an unorganized person.

job_title: Special Research Faculty in Blacksburg, VA
pros: It was a state job, had decent benefits and better retirement contributions than my private sector contributions. Technically I had holidays observed by the state off. Was a solid and stable job.
cons: Health benefits were ok, not as good as what I had in the private sector. I was a researcher so holidays and breaks were often not observed, all major holidays were though. Raises were scarce unless given by the state. Employment is dependent on research grant funding.

review_title: Virginia Tech is an amazing place to work geographically located in an outdoor wonderland.
pros: The culture and spirit of community and inclusion is at the heart of all interactions within the university and Town of Blacksburg.
cons: While the university as a whole is incredible, one should be careful because not all departments have a trusting culture.

review_title: Spend all day in lab viewing driving videos and recording specified information.
pros: It is very flexible for students.  Allows one to choose their own schedule and are able to take off days as needed.
cons: Very repetitive and boring.  Requires one to concentrate on the same situations everyday all day.  While not a very difficult job it is mentally taxing and can leave you frustrated.

review_title: The dept. I work in is relatively small and a great place--I've heard the opposite is true in some departments.
pros: Lots of training opportunities and tuition reimbursement if you are pursing an advanced degree. The campus is beautiful and Blacksburg is a wonderful town.
cons: Lower pay than the private sector. Job security that was once a given is no longer applicable. University is moving toward a business model that in no way benefits the employee or consumer (student).

review_title: Overall great experience working in VT Labs as paid Undergraduate Researcher
pros: Get freedom to pick on lots of interesting projects related to your major. Different locations and laboratories dedicated to researching different topics. Can do hands-on work or other research work if preferred.
cons: Very few challenges associated with working part-time as a researcher at Virginia Tech. There is an hourly limit per week for some jobs worked, and this can be a hassle in weeks where there is a time crunch to meet a deadline.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
- having Icat(institute for creativity art and technology ) as a  bridge between art and science
- everyone do their best to grow the community
- lots of potential(cube, motion captures,...) for data visualization
cons: its tech university so its not Art don't expect to much even after opening the moss center for the art still its tech university, there should be balance between art and tech even today's art IS  technology but still there should be balance between two.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
Virginia Tech provides a great environment for graduate students.  Tech provides a traditional graduate assistantship one could expect at any university, and provides the means necessary to succeed.  I'm working with a great advisor in a well-run department, so I haven't had any problems -- your mileage varies by adviser and department.

The school pays most of the cost for health insurance for graduate students on an assistantship.
cons: You don't get paid very much, although what you do get paid goes a long way in Blacksburg.  You also don't get some traditional job benefits, like 401k.

pros: Wonderful people and strong sense of community across campus. Beautiful work environment and you receive nice benefits as a full time employee. Professional development is also strongly encouraged and widely available.
cons: Opportunities for advancement within your own department are rare.  Raises are also rare and modest (usually just a cost of living increase).  Also, regularly worked 60 to even 70 hr/wk for a few years before I received full time assistance, though time off was flexible (but only when we weren't busy, which was almost always).

review_title: Strong in engineering, science and agriculture
job_title: Administrative Professional Faculty in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
1. The campus is beautiful and clean
2. VT has a strong STEM portfolio including engineering, basic sciences, agriculture, vet medicine, and now the Carillion School of Medicine
3. Blacksburg and Christiansburg are nice places to raise children
4. The new Moss Arts Center offers cultural programming, which was seriously lacking in the past
5. faculty and staff relations are decent and for the most part they get along well on a day to day basis
cons:
1. VT honors the military culture and chain of command, which means in your day to day work routine you will have to navigate this through waiting for approvals, forms, and routing trivial things to many people for their input/changes. 
2. Due to it's long history of intentional exclusion and Southern culture, VT is not as diverse as its higher ed peers across the US.  A small group of people are trying to change this but it is difficult and slow. It doesn't help that VT tends to hire VT alumni, so the staff aren't invested in change because they haven't seen it at other places.
3. Blacksburg is boring, especially for young, single professionals.  
4. Faculty are overextended and stressed out, same as any other institution of higher ed, and working with them is challenging
5. managing budgetary pressures and bureaucratic redundancies are part of the job
6. VT is big and complex and you will never really be effective or understand what is going on beyond your little pocket of work unless you invest A LOT of time and energy educating yourself about the activities and outcomes beyond your unit. It is basically a second job figuring out what is going on around you and how it effects your work and planning for the future.

review_title: Only expect a raise or promotion if someone leaves or you have another offer on the table.
job_title: Computer Support Analyst in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Great School to be around.  Great potential for personal development with the University.  Great people to work with in terms of personality (not skills)
cons: Most people in the department are old, and using brand new computers with a 1992 mentality. ("You mean I need to turn on the printer before I click Print?!"). Management gets comfortable with you working in your current position (Blames it on State Budget).  Yet when you present an external job offer, they eventually match it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia Tech is a great community with rigorous research standards. The school is located in Blacksburg, VA which offers plenty of activities to take the necessary breaks from work, but doesn't have too many distractions to keep one from completing their research.
cons: Graduate teaching assistants training could be more robust. Lots of paperwork and signature requirements to get research credits processed for graduation.

review_title: Can get boring but the best college job you can get
pros:
People are kind and enjoy their work; working with people who enjoy and are good at their job makes the work environment better.

Make your own hours, always was able to balance my work to study balance easily.

Closed on weekends so you can keep your social activities.
cons:
When the Archive closes at 5pm that's it; you have to schedule your classes around getting your hours in during 8am and 5pm.

Job can get a little boring at times but it's still better than working food service.

review_title: Strong engineering school, weak in life sciences, poor leadership
pros: This is a good engineering school. Large campus with critical mass in many disciplines. Good quality of life with short commutes and many outdoors opportunities. Compensation and benefits are good.
cons: The town is very small and very far from anything that looks like a city. Travel often is nightmare with long drives or poor airline connections.

pros: State Job with good benefits that are very comprehensive, flexible/alternate schedules are available, generous paid holidays even after you take into account the winter furlough, and good job security.
cons: The nature of academics is to be very status-conscious which leads to some coworkers being unintentionally demeaning to people with lesser educational achievements. Very understaffed with a lot of personalities in play.

review_title: A good university which can use much needed improvements
pros:
1 The campus is beautiful and clean
2 The benefits are excellent
3 VT has some good faculty
4 Very flexible work hours
cons:
1 Not a city campus so life is boring for single professionals
2 Located in a small town with the nearest city ~3 hours away
3 So called 'Parking Services' is actually a high profit business
4 VT is not able to retain top notch faculty

review_title: Learn How to Live to Serve, (Ut Prosim), and Invent the Future
pros: A community that is focused on learning, accepting and engaging with all members, students, faculty, cultures. A place where while feeding you interests, you learn there are no limits.
cons: Only con is the weather can be a bit unpredictable (thanks global climate change), and tuition for both in-state and out-of-state will have you likely living in debt for some chunk of life, but who isn't?

pros: Virginia Tech offers a career growing opportunity that most collegiate students search for while in college. It is great for my schedule, a relaxed environment, and very challenging mentally.
cons: For me, it is a long drive from where I live. This would be the only downfall to the job, whereas, everything else is great.

review_title: Good place to get your graduate degree despite poor communication with university administration
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Great learning experiences with principal investigators and advisers.  Responsibility and autonomy lead to professional growth.  Virginia tech is top class in preparing practitioners of engineering.
cons: University relations at Virginia Tech is constantly disappointing in their information sharing with the campus community.  Causes a "rift" between university and departmental administration.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
University/Academic setting
Facilities are very good
Meet lot of people
Small town, you feel part of the community
cons:
Postdoctoral research positions are cheap "very skilled labor" for universities so that they can compete with other research organizations. It may be essential if you are pursuing an academic career in a research university or national lab. But, a postdoc in itself has no future and you are even more expendable than a graduate student. The working conditions are really bad. 

In general postdocs positions are filled by Indian and Chinese scholars who are trying to stay in the country after they graduated. Sort of the hispanic equivalent of manual labor in the sciences and engineering.

review_title: Good people, state benefits, mid-level pay
pros: Great people and environment to live in.  Primary and Secondary schools are very good.  University is very diverse and has many activities.  I find they support long-term employment and value committment to the institution.
cons: State-run budget makes for very slow raises and cost of living increases.  Big institution implies a lot of overhead and a lot of policies to navigate.

job_title: Food Production Supervisor in Blacksburg, VA
pros: They have good benefits and the work is fairly easy. I have been able to learn a lot about cooking through working here and get a lot of time off 1-2 months throughout the year.
cons: The pay reflects the difficulty of the job. The raises barely keep up with inflation. The tenancy of management to hire outside is upsetting. Combined the long term prospect of career advance and a sustainable pay are demoralizing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia Tech campus is huge and beautiful. The pay for research assistants is decent if you consider the low cost of living for Blacksburg. You also get a plenty of opportunity to grow professionally and conduct quality research.
cons: It is very difficult to travel to nearby cities from Blacksburg campus. It takes about an hour just to reach the nearest airport.

review_title: Terrible communication, little respect for student schedule, great job satisfaction
pros: Whenever I can help a student out, it makes all the other hardships worth it. Great benefits, considering housing is free and you work where you live (no commute).
cons: Bad communication from upper management in HRL, questionable decisions made above you, very little advance notice on deadlines, too much emphasis on issues that don't seem pressing, lack solid policy training

review_title: Good Work Environment ; Not Great for Promotion
job_title: Operations Support Specialist in Blacksburg, VA
pros: The benefits and time off were fantastic, and the overall environment was pretty good.
cons: There's not a lot of room for advancement or upward mobility just due to the nature that people tend to hold onto their jobs. If you're okay with staying in the same position for years then this would be a good fit, if not, you're going to find yourself "stuck"

pros: It is nice to receive tuition remission and health benefits. Faculty will also understand when it is busy due to finals or midterms and ease off on your schedule.
cons: I was roped into many, many administrative tasks that offered a lot of professional expertise for which I normally get compensated a much more competitive value. It was tough to see many GAs being underutilized, while I was over-relied on for the particular skills I offerred.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
Virginia Tech has provided me continuous funding for my phd and also allowed me to work as an instructor.  Good health insurance plans are available.  All staff are helpful and prompt. 
Offices, labs and even gyms are well maintained. Excellent support for international students.
cons: Funding for conference travel is often low. While most funding opportunities are advertised,  some are difficult to learn about. These opportunities should be broadcast more widely to select from a wider talent pool.

review_title: Great Experience if you have the right supervisor
pros: Had a great experience at Virginia Tech.  It was a nice team to work with until a change in leadership led to abusive work environment.
cons: Change in director and supervisor caused the whole team to go downhill and it became a toxic environment to work with.  The wrong leadership can destroy a team and affect morale severely.

review_title: Fantastic institution to conduct research and work with bright students
pros: I have been associated with 4 higher ed institutions and the quality of research, students and colleagues at Virginia Tech is second to none. Tech is an institution that is leading the industry and collaborating with many Fortune 50 and 500 companies.
cons: Blacksburg is small. Like, really small. Luckily Tech understands this and provides strong travel funding, but it's small.

review_title: I worked as a graduate research assistant in the department of mechanical engineering and on my phd.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: very nice and innovative atmosphere. lots of interesting things happening on a day to day basis but old school type of building for mechanical engineering (updated now)
cons: It wasn't always extremely modern and collaborative. sometimes you would find yourself in fierce competition to other graduate students

pros: Flexible  hours; as long as the work gets done, I can come to campus at any time. The department has been great for me at making sure your funding is covered each semester.
cons: As expected of a graduate student, there are a lot of hours needed to get work done. On a grad student salary, there is no overtime pay as expected, but my advisor is very reasonable regarding work and encourages work-life balance.

pros:
* Work environment is great!
* Co-workers are very nice.
* Boss is awesome.
* Free school if you are a Faculty member.
* Insurance & retirement are great.
cons:
* Most people work in cubicles in E.S. which is kinda lame.
* Pay is lower than industry but the work environment makes up for it.
* There is lots of "red tape" for doing things so for full blown software engineers it could be a rough environment for getting stuff done. Auditing is taken VERY seriously.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant at Virginia Tech
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Engineering school is pretty good and well ranked. Most of the companies hiring on campusare linked to federal contracts
cons: If you are looking for big city employers, there maybe a lack of those, most of the big city ones coming mostly from DC

pros: Great work environment. Nice campus. everyone is friendly. I have been here for three years. they pay employee tuition for degree. I got a Master degree here in two years when I am working as full time. Great place to live. Very peaceful.
cons: less activities comparing with big cities. The town is too small and sometime is boring. Too far from big cities. The closest ones are Charlotte and DC which is 3 hrs and 4 and half hrs away.

pros: Great pay for a student job, immediate boss was supportive, flexible working hours, clean and professional working environment, fun coworkers
cons: Job itself can be quite monotonous, staff members of VTTI outside of the data reductionist department seem somewhat stand-offish and critical of the reductionists, VTTI is not on-campus

job_title: Student Athlete Tutor in Blacksburg, VA
pros: If you like working with students or helping students, it definitely offers some great opportunities to achieve this goal. You can build your own schedule and if you end up having a conflict, you can reschedule appointments without too much complication.
cons: I only worked for a semester, but I had to step down because I had to focus on my studies. I did not see any problems working there, my manager was very understanding and helped me a lot along the way.

review_title: Very flexible, was able to work my way up while going to school.
pros: They will schedule you around your classes, and are willing to accommodate if you need to take time off to do homework or study. Also, was free to solve problems my own way, without being micromanaged too much.
cons: Older people will question technological solutions to problems, and sometimes being the hourly worker means doing some very boring tasks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Broad scientific community. High quality faculty. good instructors. sense of service to community and state. generally friendly atmosphere. good pay for graduate assistants. good campus food
cons: large classes at undergrad level, research focused advisers who can sometimes undervalue educational goals of a student. Facilities and space accommodations can be rough

job_title: Food Service Assistant Senior in Blacksburg, VA
pros: State benefits. Getting a free meal. Interacting with students. Being part of a top notch facilities.
cons: Understaffed. Not flexible with hours, hard to get an ideal shift if you are new. Lack of universal communication between all levels of staff.

pros: good benefits, days off with pay, holiday off with pay, sick leave paid, family leave, lots of parking retirement benefits, medical insurances, life insurance paid
cons: nepatism, favorites treated special, raises should be to all just not special pets, family should not be hired,supervisors should set good examples, coming yo work on time, taking the time lunch not using state vehicles for personal use

review_title: dining hall jobs are great for students.
pros: flexible hours (even for the full-time), nice people, decent pay, free meal each shift, if you're a hard worker it's pretty easy to get promoted.
cons: it's easy to get promoted, but there's not much incentive to become a manager.. pay raise isn't much compared to all the extra responsibilities they give you.

pros: Blacksburg is a very nice place to live and the Virginia Tech campus is nice as well. A lot of resources and a large variety of interesting work going on
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy so it is hard to get things done. Some things seem to be judged more on politics rather than actual merit

job_title: Learning Assistant (LA) for CEE 4804 in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
Being a learning assistant is a wonderful job to have at Virginia Tech. Some of the pros of this job are:
- great compensation
- an opportunity to interact with other learning assistants and students
- ability to improve your communication skills
cons: The only "con" that I would have is that sometimes meetings are so short that they would have been better served to communicate that information via email.  However, then we wouldn't get to meet in person as much!

job_title: Associate Professor in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Strong sense of community and supportive environment. 
Fairly good students.
Northern Virginia Campus is in a very good location
Some solid faculty and research labs
cons:
Too bureaucratic and not very dynamic
Unclear priorities and decision making channels
Faculty salaries lower than many peer institutions 
Trying to be "nice", many faculty frequently do not provide honest feedback to students and colleagues

pros: The job is great for college students because it has very flexible hours and pretty solid pay. It also looks pretty good on a resume as research experience. Frequent breaks
cons: The job can be fairly monotonous as it is basically data entry, but this is outweighed by the flexibility and pay for most people.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia tech is a good place to do research work. It is located in small town of Blacksburg away from traffic hassles. The library facilities are very good. There is good collaborative research opportunities.
cons: Virginia tech is away from major cities and the nearest airport is 50 miles away. This is usually not a problem since average person does not travel more than once or twice.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: As a graduate student assistant, I take labs for undergraduate classes. It is a fresh revision of those basics as every now and again, students come up with new and interesting questions/problems. To be able to take on this challenge, you really need to have a sound understanding of the course yourself. This is a nice way to keep in touch with your basics.
cons: Sometimes the work load adds extra burden, especially as a graduate student.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: They have a good and innovative environment. The location is really nice and the pay is generous for a graduate research assistant.
cons: Things are a bit slow and they have problems managing the projects. It's not very close to industry since it is located in a small town in the middle of no where.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant & Graduate Teaching Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Virginia Tech is an amazing school located in this amazing college town. Every thing is really cheap and CoED friendly. Lots of opportunities for students to grow professionally.
cons: 4 hours out from Northern Virginia and 5 hours from my home in Maryland. But If you have car you can make the drive home or use the really awesome VT carpool facebook page.

review_title: Recommend for Graduate School in CEE
pros: There are many high quality course, they are well designed. There are all many smart peoples and nice professors. They are well-known and very nice.
cons: The university is located in a very small town, there  are not a lot of things to do, so you can focus on your study. But sometimes you will feel boring.

pros: In a nice town to work specially for families with small children. Intellectual environment with different opportunities.  Cost of living is very low
cons: While being a small town is a pros it is also a con.  Limited activities to do in general during the year and specially during the weekend

pros: They are a great company to work for and will really support their employees. They have high standards and will help you achieve them.
cons: Some of the cons include being employed by such a huge university or brand. It can make one feel like just a number not a person.

pros: It was a lot of great experience and really helped boost my resume. The professors are usually pretty good at helping you with research and helping you with requirements you have to fulfill for classes or research. Scheduling was flexible, which was great since I was working around classes.
cons: Get used to a lot of repetitive tasks, the pay isn't good and you will definitely have to work hard to be considered for an actual research project.

review_title: Virginia Tech good place for research assistant
pros: Located in a great community, has a great number of resources available from many technical backgrounds, low cost of living, competitive compensation, good benefits, good research assistant labs available
cons: Working for government run university some paperwork may take a long time to process. Certain professors lack ideal communication skills.

pros: People are very friendly, the work seems to be very enjoyable especially if you like doing research. All in all this is a good place to work.
cons: I have not encountered many things I do not like about the company, it is still growing which adds an interesting dynamic. It also would be nice if it had a lunch room but that really isn't all that important. There aren't many cons I can think of.

review_title: Nice research environment in the DC metropolitan area
pros:
Good research environment 
Good career opportunities
Nice office in the city
Research on the fields of power system, renewable energy, bio bioinformatic etc. are conducted in Virginia Tech Research Center (VTRC) situated in Arlington.
cons:
Demanding course works
Expensive housing for Arlington research center
The most acute downside is the lack of sufficient courses. In the norther Virginia campus the number of offered courses are very limited compared to main campus in Blacksburg.

review_title: Very positive experience working at VT. Loved the interaction with faculty, students, and staff
job_title: Assistant Program Director in Falls Church, VA
pros: Many perks depending on the program you work with.  Some of the pros included flex schedule, working from home as long as the 40 hrs were completed.
cons: Limited professional growth. The possibility of growing was limited to few people. Compensation was extremely low for the amount of responsibility.

review_title: As a student it was great!
pros: It is great to work for the University as a student because they are aware of student hours and give flexible working times. They are very accommodating and want to help you grow as well.
cons: As the House Supervisor your expected to be on call almost 24/7. I've heard working in the dining halls can be very fast-paced and a little stressful. It is harder to get time off.

review_title: Being an orientation leader at Virginia Tech
pros: Dakota! He was amazing! He's one of the biggest reasons I enjoyed my job so much. Everyone else in management was amazing and outgoing as well. The best part of the job is getting to meat 30 hokies, 4 days a week for a month!
cons: We had 18-hour work days but it was all worth it because of all the amazing people you get to meet.

review_title: Meaningful work and small-town living at its best
pros: Geographical location is beautiful, wonderful supportive community, great family place;  exposure to lots of great information, speakers, arts and entertainment, and sports with the college community.  As an organization, VT shares many of the challenges that large organizations have, the the passion of this community is invigorating.
cons: Large, hierarchical, bureaucratic, traditional organization.  Communication is less-than-transparent, and change is slow...

review_title: Can be a great place to work!
pros: Plenty of room to grow and learn new skills, connect with others for networking opportunities. Benefits are good, relatively easy to get time off when requested.
cons: Not all departments are the same, research them carefully before applying. Some want you to be all you can be and more while others only want robots.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
1)  Moderate to low teaching load
2)  Nice faculty to work with
3)  Nice environment : small town , nice weather , pretty landscape...
cons:
1) The contract usually needs to be reviewed on a yearly base
2) The health insurance benefits do not include dental or vision
3) Limited contribution to career if not seeking a teaching position

review_title: Great employer, wish they had more jobs for non-research-track people
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Great colleagues, a solid benefits package, beautiful scenery, and overall very good students. Being able to commute every day by bus for free is a great bonus too.
cons: The main drawback is that unless you're heavily into research and have a strong "pedigree" you can't get into a tenure-track position and there are limited opportunities for faculty who don't fit the research-oriented mold.

review_title: They were extremely friendly and good to work with.
pros: The coworkers are friendly and helpful and always willing to explain something to you when you don't understand.
cons: Getting in touch with some professors is difficult because of their class schedules and office hours.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: nice people, quite place, good weather, low compensate, where are places for hiking and 4 hours to DC. residence are mainly students and faculty.
cons: small place, not much entertainment. do not have Wal-Mart. low salary for research assistance or TA. just has a small shopping mall.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: The highest point in my career so far, where I felt that I am not just working for money but for something bigger.
cons: Research in Academia is not that amazing, but enough to get you by. Small city but will not change anything about it...except for blue grass music

pros: Benefits, salary, location - can't be beat.  8% retirement fund matching, state health insurance, lots of vacation, generous salary - all in a relaxed environment with low cost of living.  Everyone is very engaged and enjoys the work - no ladder climbers or people who just want a paycheck.
cons: None to speak of.  Um... Parking permits on campus are expensive?

pros: The campus is beautiful.  Other Instructors are nice, knowledgeable, and willing to help you.  New and working equipment in every room.
cons: However, the Dean has a really nasty attitude problem and will not help in a serious situation.   She only cares about numbers and keeping her job.  The program directors only do the dirty work for the Dean.  Students that should fail have to get pushed through to get the numbers to balance.  The students can barely add and subtract.  It's sad.  Students are allowed to cheat and that's not fair.

job_title: IT Student Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros: I really like my job, but not everybody who works at Tech is gonna be able to have this job. I worked for dining services before which was ok too.
cons: None from my point of view. I really like working in the computer lab, and my boss is nice.

pros: The leadership is stellar, the support is unmatched, and the pay is very fair. On top of all of that, the benefits package is second to none. Take a job with Virginia Tech without hesitation.
cons: Traveling to and from the Blacksburg campus can be difficult although the campus and the town are wonderful places to live and work.

job_title: Assistant Director of Academic Advising in Blacksburg, VA
pros: Beautiful location, good school in general
cons: Staff pay is extremely low, no potential for growth. Salary not commensurate with experience or responsibilities. Upper admin get paid much higher than staff. Titles mattered too much.

pros: The working time is decided by yourself, you can co-work with so many talented people here, and there are a lot of new knowledge to learn.
cons: The research here is more theoretical and will be a little boring. Many of the research product can not used in industry.

review_title: Virginia Tech is a great place to study and do research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Blacksburg, VA
pros:
Inter-disciplinary research
State of the art research
Very supportive faculty
Very good research facilities
Beautiful surroundings
Good summer and spring weather
cons: Not much exposure to big city. More options for summer classes will be very useful. More international restaurants will be good.

review_title: Great people and great work environment. It was like a family.
